"Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough" was the first short film of Michael Jackson's solo career, filmed in 1979 for the No. 1 hit single from 'Off the Wall.' "Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough," directed by Nick Saxon, was the jumping off point for the elaborate and groundbreaking "short films" Michael would go on to create throughout his career.

From the album Off the Wall, released August 10, 1979
Released as a single July 10, 1979

THE SHORT FILM
Director: Nick Saxon

Although all of Michael Jackson's music videos are referred to as short films, the short films for Off the Wall, Michael's first solo album for Epic Records, are more classic "music videos," as they are performance clips rather than scripted stories.  Michael's short film for "Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough" was the first of the three short films produced for recordings from that album. The single reached No. 1 in eight countries in 1979, topping Billboard's Hot 100, Hot Soul Singles and Hot Disco Singles charts as well as the Cash Box Top 100.

"Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough" was certified Gold by the Recording Industry Association of America on November 29, 1979, and Platinum on February 14, 1989. The song won Michael his first solo Grammy Award for Best Male R&B Vocal Performance in 1980, as well as his first American Music Award for Favorite Single (Soul/R&B). "Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough" was ranked No. 9 on the 100 Best Songs of the '70s by NME and No. 16 on VH1's list of 100 Greatest Dance Songs.

"That song means a lot to me because it was the first song I wrote as a whole," Michael wrote in his 1988 memoir Moonwalk. "'Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough' was my first big chance, and it went straight to Number One. It was the song that won me my first Grammy. Quincy had the confidence in me to encourage me to go into the studio by myself, which I appreciated."

The short film featured Michael in performance against a dazzling background of geometric shapes and patterns. Wearing a tuxedo similar to his outfit on the Off the Wall album cover, Jackson sings and dances to the song, at one point even dancing with two other clones of himself, achieved through the magic of special effects.

Michael Jackson - Don’t Stop 'Til You Get Enough (Official Video)

Renowned as one of the most influential pop artists of all time, Michael Jackson carved out a legendary career with a repertoire of timeless music. Among his iconic works, “Don’t Stop 'Til You Get Enough” stands out as a defining moment. Released in 1979, this track marked a significant milestone in Michael's solo career. It was not just another hit; it was a creative leap that solidified his place in music history.

The Song and its Impact

“Don’t Stop 'Til You Get Enough” was the lead single from Michael Jackson's critically acclaimed album 'Off the Wall'. Written and composed by Jackson himself, the song demonstrated his mastery in blending pop, rock, and disco elements into a new sound that was fresh and invigorating. Under the expert production of Quincy Jones, Jackson was able to refine his artistic vision, creating a track that would resonate with audiences worldwide.

Released on July 10, 1979, the single rapidly climbed music charts across the globe, reaching the No. 1 spot in eight countries. In the United States, it topped the Billboard Hot 100, Hot Soul Singles, and Hot Disco Singles charts. Beyond its commercial success, the song was embraced by critics and the music community, earning Jackson his first solo Grammy Award for Best Male R&B Vocal Performance in 1980. Moreover, it received the American Music Award for Favorite Single (Soul/R&B), further cementing its legacy in music history.

The Innovative Music Video

The music video for “Don’t Stop 'Til You Get Enough” was Michael Jackson’s first short film as a solo artist. Directed by Nick Saxon, the video set the stage for Jackson's future work in music video production, where he continually pushed the boundaries of creativity and storytelling. Though simpler than his later short films such as “Thriller” or “Smooth Criminal”, this video was pivotal in showcasing his charisma and indefatigable energy as a performer.

In the video, Jackson is seen against a mesmerizing backdrop of geometric shapes and kaleidoscopic patterns. Dressed in a tuxedo reminiscent of the one he wore on the 'Off the Wall' album cover, Michael's dance moves are synchronized with the funk-infused beats of the song. One of the video’s most memorable sequences is the use of special effects to create two additional “clones” of Michael, dancing alongside him, which captured viewers' imaginations and highlighted the video's visual creativity.

Legacy and Cultural Significance

"Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough" holds a special place in Michael Jackson's discography. It was a trailblazer track that opened the door to his subsequent successes, influencing artists across generations. It was celebrated by music enthusiasts and the press alike, ranking No. 9 on NME's list of the 100 Best Songs of the '70s and No. 16 on VH1's list of 100 Greatest Dance Songs.

For Michael Jackson, the song carried personal significance. In his 1988 memoir "Moonwalk," he expressed his pride in creating a song that represented a major breakthrough in his career. He credited Quincy Jones with having the faith in him to take such creative risks, a gesture that meant a lot to him both professionally and personally. This track was not only a commercial success but also an artistic endeavor that showcased Jackson's dedication to his craft.

Conclusion

Michael Jackson’s “Don’t Stop 'Til You Get Enough” is much more than a feel-good hit from the disco era – it’s a testament to the enduring power of music to uplift and inspire. Its seamless fusion of rhythm, vocals, and dance continues to captivate audiences, transcending time and trends. This song set the stage for Michael's illustrious career, predicting the genius that he would bring to music and entertainment through his innovative artistry.

The song's vast cultural impact, electrifying music video, and success have undoubtedly earned it a place in music history. Fans of all ages continue to enjoy its infectious energy, keeping the spirit of Michael Jackson’s music alive for generations to come.
